description: Pep Hamilton hasn't wasted any time getting to know the Chargers' next face of the franchise and eventual successor to Philip Rivers. This, of course, is Justin Herbert, whom the Chargers drafted with the sixth overall pick in last month's NFL draft. Herbert will compete with veteran quarterback Tyrod Taylor, who' s been referred to by Chargers coach Anthony Lynn as...
text:
Pep Hamilton hasn't wasted any time getting to know the Chargers' next face of
the franchise and eventual successor to Philip Rivers.

This, of course, is Justin Herbert, whom the Chargers drafted with the sixth
overall pick in last month's NFL draft. Perhaps it's not fair to label a
rookie quarterback as a "face of a franchise," but that's what many expect
from him in the years to come, and Hamilton was hired to guide Herbert to that
esteemed status.

There's plenty of pressure on the Chargers' new quarterbacks coach, but you
couldn't tell from Wednesday's introductory Zoom call. The easygoing Hamilton
bantered with reporters and poked fun at one's quarantine mustache (this
reporter).

"Is that a real mustache?" Hamilton asked. "What was your question again?"

The question: How tough is it to balance a quarterback competition while
trying to groom a first-round quarterback at the same time?

Herbert will compete with veteran quarterback Tyrod Taylor, who's been
referred to by Chargers coach Anthony Lynn as being in the driver's seat to
start.

Hamilton, 45, wasn't stalling to answer the question. He's seen all types of
quarterback battles dating back to his first coaching gig as Howard's
quarterbacks coach in 1997, one year after playing quarterback for the
university. Hamilton has coached for the New York Jets, San Francisco 49ers,
Chicago Bears and Cleveland Browns.

He was instrumental in the development of former star quarterback Andrew Luck
as an assistant coach at Stanford and with the Indianapolis Colts. Hamilton
was Luck's offensive coordinator from 2013 to 2015.

So back to the question.

"I don't know that it's necessarily a tough thing to do," Hamilton said. "I
think whenever we get on the field, I think guys are going to organically
separate themselves. I do think that football is such that when given the
opportunity to go out and play, and play at a level that's going to give our
team a chance to win games, it shows through reps and it shows in time."

Hamilton and the Chargers don't plan on rushing Herbert's development, but
they're expecting the former Oregon quarterback to push Taylor for the
starting gig.

"They are different players," Hamilton said when asked if there are any
similarities between Herbert and Luck. "But you know, I think the one thing
that they have in common is the fact that they were drafted with the
expectation of being able to come in and play at a high level whenever they
get the opportunity to play. So we're preparing Justin to be ready to come in
and compete to play from Day 1."

Hamilton, who was officially hired this month, hasn't worked with Herbert in
person, but he's gotten to know him virtually, saying the two have had many
football conversations that have gone into the wee hours of the night.

"Smart kid," Hamilton said of Herbert. "Very smart. Football is important to
him.  I'm excited to see that he's a student of the game."

Hamilton hasn't coached in the NFL since 2016. He was an assistant head coach
at Michigan for two seasons and was the general manager and head coach of the
XFL's DC Defenders for five games before the startup league folded in April.

Hamilton wasn't unemployed for long. He has another coaching gig, one with
plenty of pressure, but that's nothing new to him.

CHARGERS REOPEN FACILITY

The Chargers reopened their facility Tuesday with only a few executives
allowed inside the Costa Mesa building.

They plan to slowly allow more people inside the facility in the coming days
while following all safety guidelines. NFL facilities were closed two months
ago because of the coronavirus pandemic and were allowed to reopen last week.

The next phase would be to allow players and coaches inside the building and
eventually on the practice field, but there's no telling when that time will
come.

Right tackle Bryan Bulaga, the Chargers' free-agent acquisition, has spent his
offseason in Florida. Bulaga said he's planning to gradually move into his new
Los Angeles home in the next few weeks.

Bulaga is itching to meet his new teammates in person, but he's skeptical
about potentially jumping into a mandatory minicamp next month if the league
and the state allows it.

"I don't think we can just go out there for a week of minicamp and do it how
we normally do it," Bulaga said. "Put on helmets and fly around and do that. I
don't see how that's possible. I think there's health risk involved there, not
coronavirus health, but with guys' bodies; hamstrings, knees.

"We haven't done any football movements and then you're going to put us in
front of each other and then say, 'Hey, go at it.' I don't know if that's
going to work out, but I can see it more of a jog through tempo. More teaching
than actually live speed."

HARRIS' FRESH START

First-year Chargers cornerback Chris Harris Jr. was named to the league's
2010s All-Decade Team in April. That's one of many awards Harris earned during
his nine seasons with the Denver Broncos.

Harris, 30, is hoping a fresh start with the Chargers will lead to more
awards, including the prestigious Hall of Fame.

"Last year, there was a lot of stuff going on with me," Harris said about his
final year with the Broncos, which included trade rumors. "Mentally, you never
know how stuff wears down on you. I think it just did. Naturally as a human it
did. Going into this year, I feel so happy. I got a clear mind and I'm hungry.
I'm not done. I got a lot of goals I want to achieve. I want to be in the Hall
of Fame. I want to continue to get Pro Bowls and All-Pros."

Before the rocky ending, the Broncos signed Harris as an undrafted free agent
in 2011 out of the University of Kansas. He made four Pro Bowls, one First-
Team All-Pro, two Second-Team All-Pros and won Super Bowl 50.

There was plenty of good for Harris in Denver, a stint that started with
Chargers defensive backs coach Ron Milus grooming the undrafted free agent.
Milus held the same position in Denver and coached Harris from 2011 to 2012.

"Always play that slot (cornerback position)," Harris recalled what Milus told
him in Denver. "He said that's my spot. That's one thing he told me. He said,
'Whatever you do, if you can play outside or safety, always try to play that
slot.' He said I'm one of the best at it."

One of the Chargers' intriguing offseason storylines is where Harris and
Desmond King will line up in the secondary this season. King was named First-
Team All-Pro as a slot cornerback in 2018.

title: Chargers hire Pep Hamilton to groom Justin Herbert, but no pressure
html:
Pep Hamilton hasn't wasted any time getting to know the Chargers' next face of the franchise and eventual successor to Philip Rivers.

This, of course, is Justin Herbert, whom the Chargers drafted with the sixth overall pick in last month's NFL draft. Perhaps it's not fair to label a rookie quarterback as a "face of a franchise," but that's what many expect from him in the years to come, and Hamilton was hired to guide Herbert to that esteemed status.

There's plenty of pressure on the Chargers' new quarterbacks coach, but you couldn't tell from Wednesday's introductory Zoom call. The easygoing Hamilton bantered with reporters and poked fun at one's quarantine mustache (this reporter).

"Is that a real mustache?" Hamilton asked. "What was your question again?"

The question: How tough is it to balance a quarterback competition while trying to groom a first-round quarterback at the same time?

Herbert will compete with veteran quarterback Tyrod Taylor, who's been referred to by Chargers coach Anthony Lynn as being in the driver's seat to start.

Hamilton, 45, wasn't stalling to answer the question. He's seen all types of quarterback battles dating back to his first coaching gig as Howard's quarterbacks coach in 1997, one year after playing quarterback for the university. Hamilton has coached for the New York Jets, San Francisco 49ers, Chicago Bears and Cleveland Browns.

He was instrumental in the development of former star quarterback Andrew Luck as an assistant coach at Stanford and with the Indianapolis Colts. Hamilton was Luck's offensive coordinator from 2013 to 2015.

So back to the question.

"I don't know that it's necessarily a tough thing to do," Hamilton said. "I think whenever we get on the field, I think guys are going to organically separate themselves. I do think that football is such that when given the opportunity to go out and play, and play at a level that's going to give our team a chance to win games, it shows through reps and it shows in time."

Hamilton and the Chargers don't plan on rushing Herbert's development, but they're expecting the former Oregon quarterback to push Taylor for the starting gig.

"They are different players," Hamilton said when asked if there are any similarities between Herbert and Luck. "But you know, I think the one thing that they have in common is the fact that they were drafted with the expectation of being able to come in and play at a high level whenever they get the opportunity to play. So we're preparing Justin to be ready to come in and compete to play from Day 1."

Hamilton, who was officially hired this month, hasn't worked with Herbert in person, but he's gotten to know him virtually, saying the two have had many football conversations that have gone into the wee hours of the night.

"Smart kid," Hamilton said of Herbert. "Very smart. Football is important to him. … I'm excited to see that he's a student of the game."

Hamilton hasn't coached in the NFL since 2016. He was an assistant head coach at Michigan for two seasons and was the general manager and head coach of the XFL's DC Defenders for five games before the startup league folded in April.

Hamilton wasn't unemployed for long. He has another coaching gig, one with plenty of pressure, but that's nothing new to him.

CHARGERS REOPEN FACILITY

The Chargers reopened their facility Tuesday with only a few executives allowed inside the Costa Mesa building.

They plan to slowly allow more people inside the facility in the coming days while following all safety guidelines. NFL facilities were closed two months ago because of the coronavirus pandemic and were allowed to reopen last week.

The next phase would be to allow players and coaches inside the building and eventually on the practice field, but there's no telling when that time will come.

Right tackle Bryan Bulaga, the Chargers' free-agent acquisition, has spent his offseason in Florida. Bulaga said he's planning to gradually move into his new Los Angeles home in the next few weeks.

Bulaga is itching to meet his new teammates in person, but he's skeptical about potentially jumping into a mandatory minicamp next month if the league and the state allows it.

"I don't think we can just go out there for a week of minicamp and do it how we normally do it," Bulaga said. "Put on helmets and fly around and do that. I don't see how that's possible. I think there's health risk involved there, not coronavirus health, but with guys' bodies; hamstrings, knees.

"We haven't done any football movements and then you're going to put us in front of each other and then say, 'Hey, go at it.' I don't know if that's going to work out, but I can see it more of a jog through tempo. More teaching than actually live speed."

HARRIS' FRESH START

First-year Chargers cornerback Chris Harris Jr. was named to the league's 2010s All-Decade Team in April. That's one of many awards Harris earned during his nine seasons with the Denver Broncos.

Harris, 30, is hoping a fresh start with the Chargers will lead to more awards, including the prestigious Hall of Fame.

"Last year, there was a lot of stuff going on with me," Harris said about his final year with the Broncos, which included trade rumors. "Mentally, you never know how stuff wears down on you. I think it just did. Naturally as a human it did. Going into this year, I feel so happy. I got a clear mind and I'm hungry. I'm not done. I got a lot of goals I want to achieve. I want to be in the Hall of Fame. I want to continue to get Pro Bowls and All-Pros."

Before the rocky ending, the Broncos signed Harris as an undrafted free agent in 2011 out of the University of Kansas. He made four Pro Bowls, one First-Team All-Pro, two Second-Team All-Pros and won Super Bowl 50.

There was plenty of good for Harris in Denver, a stint that started with Chargers defensive backs coach Ron Milus grooming the undrafted free agent. Milus held the same position in Denver and coached Harris from 2011 to 2012.

"Always play that slot (cornerback position)," Harris recalled what Milus told him in Denver. "He said that's my spot. That's one thing he told me. He said, 'Whatever you do, if you can play outside or safety, always try to play that slot.' He said I'm one of the best at it."

One of the Chargers' intriguing offseason storylines is where Harris and Desmond King will line up in the secondary this season. King was named First-Team All-Pro as a slot cornerback in 2018.
